questiontext.text:
Q1 — DC Resistive Circuit Analysis (Variant 1: Two Essential Nodes)

Total: 12 points | Estimated time: ~20 minutes

Consider the circuit shown below. The circuit contains a voltage source \(V_s = {@Vs@}\;\text{V}\), a current source \(I_s = {@Is@}\;\text{A}\), and three resistors: \(R_1 = {@R1@}\;\text{k}\Omega\), \(R_2 = {@R2@}\;\text{k}\Omega\), and \(R_3 = {@R3@}\;\text{k}\Omega\).

The voltage source \(V_s\) is connected on the left with \(R_1\) (horizontal) leading to Node A. From Node A, \(R_2\) connects vertically down to ground, and \(R_3\) also connects vertically down to ground. The current source \(I_s\) feeds into Node A (arrow pointing into the node).

Part A (2 pts) — Method Selection

Which analysis method is most efficient for this circuit, and how many independent equations are needed?

Select your answer: [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

Part B (3 pts) — Write the Systematic Equations (Essay)

Using the node-voltage method, write the KCL equation(s) at each essential node (excluding the reference/ground node). Show your work clearly, labelling each equation.

This part is manually graded. Write your equations in the box below.

Part C (4 pts) — Numerical Solution

Solve for the node voltage \(V_A\) (in Volts). Enter your answer to at least two decimal places.

\(V_A = \) [[input:ans2]] V [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

Part D (3 pts) — Verification & Method Justification (Essay)

Verify your answer by checking that KCL is satisfied at Node A. Also, briefly explain why the node-voltage method is the most efficient choice for this circuit (consider the number of essential nodes vs. meshes).

This part is manually graded. Write your verification and explanation below.

generalfeedback.text:
Solution for Variant 1 (Two Essential Nodes)

Part A: The node-voltage method is most efficient. There is 1 essential node (Node A) besides the reference, so only 1 equation is needed.

Part B: KCL at Node A (currents leaving = currents entering):

\[\frac{V_A - V_s}{R_1} + \frac{V_A}{R_2} + \frac{V_A}{R_3} = I_s\]

Part C: Solving for \(V_A\):

\[V_A \left(\frac{1}{R_1} + \frac{1}{R_2} + \frac{1}{R_3}\right) = \frac{V_s}{R_1} + I_s\]

\[V_A = \frac{\frac{V_s}{R_1} + I_s}{\frac{1}{R_1} + \frac{1}{R_2} + \frac{1}{R_3}} = {@ta2@}\;\text{V}\]

Part D: Verification: substitute \(V_A\) back into KCL to confirm the sum of currents at Node A equals zero. The node-voltage method is preferred because there is only 1 unknown node voltage (1 equation), whereas mesh analysis would require 2 mesh equations.

questionnote.text: V1: Vs={@Vs@}V, Is={@Is@}A, R1={@R1@}kOhm, R2={@R2@}kOhm, R3={@R3@}kOhm, V_A={@ta2@}V

questiondescription.text: DC Resistive Circuit: Two Essential Nodes — Node-Voltage Method (Easy, 12 pts)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done!

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

input.name: ans1
input.options: [[1,"Node-Voltage method; 1 equation needed"],[2,"Node-Voltage method; 2 equations needed"],[3,"Mesh-Current method; 1 equation needed"],[4,"Mesh-Current method; 2 equations needed"]]

truefeedback.text: Correct! The node-voltage method is most efficient here with only 1 equation needed (1 essential node besides the reference).

falsefeedback.text: Incorrect. This circuit has 2 essential nodes (Node A and the reference ground), giving 1 node-voltage equation. The node-voltage method is the most efficient approach.

node.description: Check Part C numerical answer for V_A

truefeedback.text: Correct! Your value of \(V_A\) matches the expected solution.

falsefeedback.text: Incorrect. The correct value is \(V_A = {@ta2@}\;\text{V}\). Check your KCL equation at Node A and make sure you converted kOhm to Ohm correctly.

questiontext.text:
Q1 — DC Resistive Circuit Analysis (Variant 2: Two Meshes)

Total: 12 points | Estimated time: ~20 minutes

Consider the circuit shown below. The circuit contains two voltage sources \(V_{s1} = {@Vs1@}\;\text{V}\) and \(V_{s2} = {@Vs2@}\;\text{V}\), and four resistors: \(R_1 = {@R1@}\;\text{k}\Omega\) (top-left branch), \(R_2 = {@R2@}\;\text{k}\Omega\) (center shared branch), \(R_3 = {@R3@}\;\text{k}\Omega\) (top-right branch), and \(R_4 = {@R4@}\;\text{k}\Omega\) (bottom-left branch).

\(V_{s1}\) is in the left loop and \(V_{s2}\) is in the right loop. Two clockwise mesh currents \(i_1\) (left mesh) and \(i_2\) (right mesh) are defined. \(R_2\) is the shared branch between the two meshes.

Part A (2 pts) — Method Selection

Which analysis method is most efficient for this circuit, and how many independent equations are needed?

Select your answer: [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

Part B (3 pts) — Write the Systematic Equations (Essay)

Using the mesh-current method, write the KVL equation for each mesh. Define mesh currents \(i_1\) (left, CW) and \(i_2\) (right, CW). Show your work clearly.

This part is manually graded. Write your equations in the box below.

Part C (4 pts) — Numerical Solution

Find the current through \(R_2\) (in mA). The current through \(R_2\) is defined as \(i_{R2} = i_1 - i_2\) (downward through \(R_2\)). Enter your answer to at least two decimal places.

\(i_{R2} = \) [[input:ans2]] mA [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

Part D (3 pts) — Verification & Method Justification (Essay)

Verify your answer by checking that KVL holds around both meshes using your computed mesh currents. Also, briefly explain why the mesh-current method is the most efficient choice for this circuit.

This part is manually graded. Write your verification and explanation below.

generalfeedback.text:
Solution for Variant 2 (Two Meshes)

Part A: The mesh-current method is most efficient. There are 2 meshes, so 2 equations are needed.

Part B: KVL equations (CW mesh currents):

Mesh 1: \(-V_{s1} + R_1 \cdot i_1 + R_2 \cdot (i_1 - i_2) + R_4 \cdot i_1 = 0\)

Mesh 2: \(R_3 \cdot i_2 + V_{s2} + R_2 \cdot (i_2 - i_1) = 0\)

Part C:

Rewriting in matrix form and solving:

Mesh 1: \((R_1 + R_2 + R_4) \cdot i_1 - R_2 \cdot i_2 = V_{s1}\)

Mesh 2: \(-R_2 \cdot i_1 + (R_2 + R_3) \cdot i_2 = -V_{s2}\)

\(i_{R2} = i_1 - i_2 = {@ta2@}\;\text{mA}\)

Part D: Verify by substituting \(i_1\) and \(i_2\) back into both KVL equations. Mesh-current is preferred because the circuit has only voltage sources and exactly 2 independent meshes, giving a clean system of 2 equations.

questionnote.text: V2: Vs1={@Vs1@}V, Vs2={@Vs2@}V, R1={@R1@}kOhm, R2={@R2@}kOhm, R3={@R3@}kOhm, R4={@R4@}kOhm, iR2={@ta2@}mA

questiondescription.text: DC Resistive Circuit: Two Meshes — Mesh-Current Method (Easy, 12 pts)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done!

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

input.name: ans1
input.options: [[1,"Mesh-Current method; 2 equations needed"],[2,"Mesh-Current method; 3 equations needed"],[3,"Node-Voltage method; 2 equations needed"],[4,"Node-Voltage method; 3 equations needed"]]

truefeedback.text: Correct! The mesh-current method is most efficient here, requiring 2 KVL equations for the 2 meshes.

falsefeedback.text: Incorrect. This circuit has 2 independent meshes and only voltage sources, making the mesh-current method most efficient with 2 equations.

node.description: Check Part C numerical answer for i_R2

truefeedback.text: Correct! Your value of \(i_{R2}\) matches the expected solution.

falsefeedback.text: Incorrect. The correct value is \(i_{R2} = {@ta2@}\;\text{mA}\). Check your mesh equations and ensure correct signs for voltage sources.

questiontext.text:
Q1 — DC Resistive Circuit Analysis (Variant 3: T-Network with Mixed Sources)

Total: 12 points | Estimated time: ~20 minutes

Consider the T-network circuit shown below. The circuit contains a voltage source \(V_s = {@Vs@}\;\text{V}\) on the left and a current source \(I_s = {@Is@}\;\text{A}\) on the right. The resistors are: \(R_1 = {@R1@}\;\text{k}\Omega\) (horizontal, left-to-center), \(R_2 = {@R2@}\;\text{k}\Omega\) (horizontal, center-to-right), and \(R_3 = {@R3@}\;\text{k}\Omega\) (vertical, center to ground).

The nodes are: Node A (left, connected to \(V_s\), so \(V_A = V_s\)), Node B (center junction of \(R_1\), \(R_2\), and \(R_3\)), and Node C (right, where \(I_s\) connects). The reference (ground) is at the bottom.

Part A (2 pts) — Method Selection

Which analysis method is most efficient for this circuit, and how many independent equations are needed?

Select your answer: [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

Part B (3 pts) — Write the Systematic Equations (Essay)

Using the node-voltage method, write the KCL equations at each unknown node. Note: Node A is known (\(V_A = V_s\)), so you only need equations at Node B and Node C.

This part is manually graded. Write your equations in the box below.

Part C (4 pts) — Numerical Solution

Solve for the node voltage \(V_B\) (in Volts) at the center node. Enter your answer to at least two decimal places.

\(V_B = \) [[input:ans2]] V [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

Part D (3 pts) — Verification & Method Justification (Essay)

Verify your answer by checking that KCL is satisfied at Node B. Also, explain why the node-voltage method was chosen for this mixed-source circuit.

This part is manually graded. Write your verification and explanation below.

generalfeedback.text:
Solution for Variant 3 (T-Network with Mixed Sources)

Part A: The node-voltage method is most efficient. Node A is constrained by \(V_s\), leaving 2 unknown node voltages (B and C), so 2 equations are needed.

Part B: KCL equations:

At Node B: \(\frac{V_B - V_s}{R_1} + \frac{V_B}{R_3} + \frac{V_B - V_C}{R_2} = 0\)

At Node C: \(\frac{V_C - V_B}{R_2} = I_s\)

Part C: From the Node C equation: \(V_C = V_B + I_s \cdot R_2\). Substituting into the Node B equation and solving gives \(V_B = {@ta2@}\;\text{V}\).

Part D: Substitute back to verify KCL. The node-voltage method is preferred because the voltage source constrains one node directly and the current source provides a simple relationship at Node C, reducing complexity.

questionnote.text: V3: Vs={@Vs@}V, Is={@Is@}A, R1={@R1@}kOhm, R2={@R2@}kOhm, R3={@R3@}kOhm, V_B={@ta2@}V

questiondescription.text: DC Resistive Circuit: T-Network with Mixed Sources — Node-Voltage Method (Easy, 12 pts)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done!

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

input.name: ans1
input.options: [[1,"Node-Voltage method; 2 equations needed"],[2,"Node-Voltage method; 3 equations needed"],[3,"Mesh-Current method; 2 equations needed"],[4,"Mesh-Current method; 3 equations needed"]]

truefeedback.text: Correct! The node-voltage method with 2 equations (for nodes B and C) is the most efficient approach for this mixed-source T-network.

falsefeedback.text: Incorrect. This circuit has 3 essential nodes (A, B, C) plus the reference. Node A is constrained (\(V_A = V_s\)), leaving 2 unknown node voltages requiring 2 node-voltage equations.

node.description: Check Part C numerical answer for V_B

truefeedback.text: Correct! Your value of \(V_B\) matches the expected solution.

falsefeedback.text: Incorrect. The correct value is \(V_B = {@ta2@}\;\text{V}\). Remember: first express \(V_C\) in terms of \(V_B\) using the current source constraint, then substitute into the KCL equation at Node B.

questiontext.text:
Q1 — DC Resistive Circuit Analysis (Variant 4: Wheatstone Bridge)

Total: 12 points | Estimated time: ~20 minutes

Consider the Wheatstone bridge circuit shown below. The circuit is powered by a voltage source \(V_s = {@Vs@}\;\text{V}\). The five resistors are arranged in a diamond (bridge) configuration:

  • \(R_1 = {@R1@}\;\text{k}\Omega\) — from Node A (top) to Node B (left)
  • \(R_2 = {@R2@}\;\text{k}\Omega\) — from Node A (top) to Node C (right)
  • \(R_3 = {@R3@}\;\text{k}\Omega\) — from Node B (left) to Node D (bottom/ground)
  • \(R_4 = {@R4@}\;\text{k}\Omega\) — from Node C (right) to Node D (bottom/ground)
  • \(R_5 = {@R5@}\;\text{k}\Omega\) — bridge resistor from Node B to Node C

Node A is connected to the positive terminal of \(V_s\) (so \(V_A = V_s\)). Node D is the ground reference (\(V_D = 0\)).

Part A (2 pts) — Method Selection

Which analysis method is most efficient for this circuit, and how many independent equations are needed?

Select your answer: [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

Part B (3 pts) — Write the Systematic Equations (Essay)

Using the node-voltage method, write the KCL equations at each unknown essential node. Note: \(V_A = V_s\) (constrained) and \(V_D = 0\) (reference), so write equations at nodes B and C.

This part is manually graded. Write your equations in the box below.

Part C (4 pts) — Numerical Solution

Find the voltage across the bridge resistor \(R_5\), defined as \(V_{BC} = V_B - V_C\) (in Volts). Enter your answer to at least two decimal places.

\(V_{BC} = \) [[input:ans2]] V [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

Part D (3 pts) — Verification & Method Justification (Essay)

Verify your answer by confirming KCL at nodes B and C. Also, discuss: under what condition would \(V_{BC} = 0\) (balanced bridge)? Is the bridge balanced for this set of values?

This part is manually graded. Write your verification and explanation below.

generalfeedback.text:
Solution for Variant 4 (Wheatstone Bridge)

Part A: The node-voltage method is most efficient. With \(V_A = V_s\) and \(V_D = 0\), there are 2 unknown node voltages (\(V_B\) and \(V_C\)), requiring 2 equations.

Part B: KCL equations:

At Node B: \(\frac{V_B - V_s}{R_1} + \frac{V_B}{R_3} + \frac{V_B - V_C}{R_5} = 0\)

At Node C: \(\frac{V_C - V_s}{R_2} + \frac{V_C}{R_4} + \frac{V_C - V_B}{R_5} = 0\)

Part C: Solving the 2x2 system yields \(V_B\) and \(V_C\), giving \(V_{BC} = V_B - V_C = {@ta2@}\;\text{V}\).

Part D: The bridge is balanced when \(R_1 \cdot R_4 = R_2 \cdot R_3\), which would make \(V_{BC} = 0\) and no current flows through \(R_5\). For the given values: \(R_1 \cdot R_4 = {@R1*R4@}\) and \(R_2 \cdot R_3 = {@R2*R3@}\), so the bridge is {@if is(R1*R4 = R2*R3) then "balanced" else "NOT balanced"@}.

questionnote.text: V4: Vs={@Vs@}V, R1={@R1@}kOhm, R2={@R2@}kOhm, R3={@R3@}kOhm, R4={@R4@}kOhm, R5={@R5@}kOhm, V_BC={@ta2@}V

questiondescription.text: DC Resistive Circuit: Wheatstone Bridge — Node-Voltage Method (Easy, 12 pts)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done!

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

input.name: ans1
input.options: [[1,"Node-Voltage method; 2 equations needed"],[2,"Node-Voltage method; 3 equations needed"],[3,"Mesh-Current method; 2 equations needed"],[4,"Mesh-Current method; 3 equations needed"]]

truefeedback.text: Correct! The node-voltage method with 2 equations is the most efficient approach for this bridge circuit.

falsefeedback.text: Incorrect. The bridge circuit has 4 essential nodes (A, B, C, D). With A constrained by \(V_s\) and D as reference ground, there are 2 unknown node voltages (\(V_B\) and \(V_C\)), requiring 2 node-voltage equations. This is more efficient than the 3 mesh equations that mesh analysis would require.

node.description: Check Part C numerical answer for V_BC

truefeedback.text: Correct! Your value of \(V_{BC}\) matches the expected solution.

falsefeedback.text: Incorrect. The correct value is \(V_{BC} = {@ta2@}\;\text{V}\). Set up the 2x2 system of node-voltage equations at nodes B and C, solve for both, then compute the difference.
